title: Economic stability outweighing values in consumer decisions
summary: Consumers still care about brand values, but economic stability is becoming the stronger driver of what they buy, where they shop, and which brands they trust. Environmental concerns fell from #4 to #9 in global worries (2024–2025); financial and geopolitical pressures lead.
detailed_analysis: Experian cites Nielsen 2026 consumer outlook: 32.8% of global shoppers feel financially worse off than last year, and 73% of those cite rising cost-of-living pressures. People are spending but directing most dollars toward core categories (food, health, household care). The shift from values-led to economics-led decisions does not mean values disappear—consumers want brands to be responsible, fair, and transparent—but they expect values to align with financial reality. Implication for identity: how people 'recalibrate' and express identity through consumption is increasingly mediated by budget and value-for-money; brand meaning and belonging must fit within that constraint.

source_articles.title: What 2026 consumer insights mean for marketers
source_articles.relevance: Primary evidence: 32.8% worse off, 73% cost-of-living; environmental #4 to #9; economic stability over values.

data_sources.contribution: Context on values vs. economics in consumer priorities.

implications: Tailor messaging to financial reality by segment (stretched vs. flexible); avoid values-only positioning without value proof.
Identity and belonging narratives should acknowledge budget and value, not only aspiration.
